awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: A Multi-Layer Learning Approach to Mobile Traffic Filtering
awd_abstract_narration:
The mobile ecosystem has become an attractive target for various types of abuses. For instance, many mobile applications leak sensitive user information, such as email addresses and location, which is a privacy issue. Second, attackers routinely disguise malware in seemingly legitimate mobile apps to launch attacks, which poses security threats. Third, many mobile apps and sites push intrusive und undesirable ads, such as auto-play and pop-ups, which harm usability. The objective of this project is to defend against these abuses in the mobile ecosystem through real-time on-device filtering of network traffic on a mobile device.

The project performs multi-layer network traffic analysis with help of machine learning. It extracts features and train learning models to produce filtering rules, which can be applied on the device. Filtering on the mobile device is particularly challenging due to limited resources, lack of visibility into packet payload, and potential collateral damage on the affected apps. The filtering approach used is envisioned as universal (i.e., applicable across all apps), automated (compared to the current practice of manually maintained privacy related data), adaptive (to the ever-changing threats), and user-centric (i.e., customized per user) while leveraging collaboration among users. The general framework will be validate in three case studies against the following abuse scenarios in the mobile ecosystem: (i) intrusive ads (ii) privacy leaks (iii) malvertising. This project is excepted to enhance the usability, privacy, and security of the mobile ecosystem and will inform policies and practices on mobile data transparency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this research was to develop new tools and techniques to improve usability, security, and privacy in the mobile and IoT ecosystems. The team's research has resulted in significant achievements and outcomes. They introduced several novel machine learning-based approaches to address usability, security, and privacy challenges in mobile and IoT ecosystems. The developed tools and techniques have demonstrated high accuracy, robustness against adversarial evasion techniques, and improved performance in detecting and countering advertising and tracking threats.


These research findings have not only contributed to academic knowledge through peer-reviewed publications but also had practical implications. The team's collaboration with the open-source privacy tools community and vendors of mobile privacy-enhancing tools has led to the incorporation of their research findings into existing products. This integration has resulted in enhanced privacy and security for users utilizing these tools.


The team actively engaged with industry and policy stakeholders, sharing their research outcomes and recommendations. Their participation in conferences, workshops, and summits, including the Adblocker Dev Summit, FTC PrivacyCon, and the Consumer Reports smart TV & streaming media privacy summit, has facilitated knowledge exchange and collaboration. Their interactions have influenced industry practices and policymaking, aiding stakeholders in making informed decisions and formulating effective policies to protect user privacy and security online. Additionally, the team has undertaken broader impact activities, such as creating a student-facilitated course on "Applied IoT" and mentoring undergraduate students. These activities have contributed to curriculum development, hands-on learning experiences, and fostering diversity in the field.

 


Last Modified: 06/12/2023
Modified by: Zubair Shafiq
